revision.text: {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Military History|class=C|B1=n|B2=y|B3=y|B4=y|B5=y|Weaponry=y|Technology=y|Balkan=yes|German=yes|WWI=yes|WWII=yes}} {{WPGUNS|class=C|importance=Mid|B-Class-1=n|B-Class-2=y|B-Class-3=y|B-Class-4=y|B-Class-5=y}} {{WikiProject Austria}} }} ==Untitled== I wonder if the existing image is concise, I've been adding images from my personal collection to many of the firearm articles, and think this might serve better: http://smg.photobucket.com/albums/v709/Vaarok/steyr95.jpg [[User:Vaarok|Vaarok]] ([[User talk:Vaarok|talk]]) 10:38, 28 January 2010 (UTC) The description is an exact copy of the Modern Firearms and Ammunition site ( world.guns.ru ). Maybe someone could rewrite this, and add info aboput the Dutch version of this weapon, rechambered to 6.5 mm? Answer: The Dutch 1895 mannlicher has nothing in common with this rifle, apart from the fact they were both made by Steyr! They are totally different designs. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/82.23.5.243|82.23.5.243]] ([[User talk:82.23.5.243|talk]]) 17:01, 14 January 2010 (UTC) == nicknamed the Ruck-Zu(rü)ck == This sentence mingles Austrian (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austria-Hungary) and Germany. Ruck-Zuck is Austrian Slang. "Landser" is a German term. The German weapon was http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gewehr_98 and not the Mannlicher — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/89.144.214.218|89.144.214.218]] ([[User talk:89.144.214.218|talk]]) 17:04, 7 February 2015 (UTC) : "Ruck-zuck" was just as well used in southern Germany (at the least). However I only ever encountered it as meaning "in a blink". Also [[de:Mannlicher Modell 1895|the German article]] makes no mention of "Ruck zurück", so I'm wondering about the authenticity of that expression. --[[User:BjKa|BjKa]] ([[User talk:BjKa|talk]]) 09:00, 10 August 2016 (UTC)
